questions.question: She passed her exam because she had a good teacher.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: She sat facing me across the table.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: He worked hard but he could not pass the exam.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses introduced by the conjunctions and, but, or, for, so, either..or, neither...nor, both..and, not only...but also.

questions.question: I am anxious to contact him.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: No one can stop him doing what he wants to.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: Always check the oil before you start the car.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: They considered him a genius.
questions.description: A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: At no time was she aware of what was happening.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: If I am late my father takes me to school.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.

questions.question: He neither drinks nor smokes.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses introduced by the conjunctions and, but, or, for, so, either..or, neither...nor, both..and, not only...but also.

questions.question: He failed the exam and nobody was surprised.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses introduced by the conjunctions and, but, or, for, so, either..or, neither...nor, both..and, not only...but also.

questions.question: He was upset but he said nothing.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses introduced by the conjunctions and, but, or, for, so, either..or, neither...nor, both..and, not only...but also.
